subject: Re: Validating xml
msgSnippet: ... call. I ... way to do ... software ... use a ... complicated than ... What I ment was validate content of the xml, not the xml structure itself. XMLUnit
messageBody:
--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbrains@r...>
wrote:
> Chad Woolley wrote:
>
> > J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
> > > moe_morten wrote:
> > >>> I want to test that I get a valid result from a webservice
call. I
> > >>> guess this involves validating the xml? Any tips on a good
way to do
> > >>> this?
> > >
> > >
> > > XMLUnit. You'll also want to get to know the XPath API.
> > > -- J. B. Rainsberger, Diaspar Software Services
> > http://www.diasparsoftware.com :: +1 416 791-8603 Let's write
software
> > that people understand
> >
> > Why not just create a DTD or XML Schema for your documents, and
use a
> > validating
> > parser? What might be the reasons to do something more
complicated than
> > this?
>
> Two different meanings of "validate." I was thinking of "check the
> content of."
>
> Of course, Chad is right. Step one: validate against an XML schema
> (since we're talking about a web service, go for XML schema).
> --
> J. B. Rainsberger,
> Diaspar Software Services
> http://www.diasparsoftware.com :: +1 416 791-8603
> Let's write software that people understand

What I ment was validate content of the xml, not the xml structure
itself. XMLUnit seems to be good...
